metadata.case_name: Election Petitioner (Appellant Voter) v. Surendra Mohanty (Respondent)

facts.text: Respondent, nominee of Utkal Congress, elected to Lok Sabha from Kendrapara parliamentary constituency, defeating Surendranath Dwivedi (Praja Socialist Party nominee, 1,20,707 votes) and Pradyumna Kishore Bal (Indian National Congress (R) nominee, 1,11,235 votes); respondent polled 1,23,680 votes.

Appellant, a voter in the constituency, filed Election Petition No. 8 of 1971 challenging respondent's election on grounds of corrupt practices under sub-ss. (3) and (4) of S. 123 of Representation of the People Act, 1951, detailed in sub-paras (i) to (iv) of para 5 of petition.
Respondent was editor of Oriya Daily 'The Kalinga' published by Kalinga Publications, Chairman Biju Patnaik, at all material times including date of election petition.
Utkal Congress symbol: water wheel (Chakra) and plough (Langala).

Allegation para 5(i): Respondent published editorial in 'The Kalinga' dated February 15, 1971, appealing to religious symbols Chakra and Langala associated with deities Jagannath and Balaram for furtherance of his election prospects and prejudicially affecting others.

Allegation para 5(ii): At public meeting Marshaghai February 15, 1971 at 5 PM, Biju Patnaik appealed to religious symbols stating Utkal Congress could eradicate unemployment and poverty with help of Jagannath and Balaram whose weapons Chakra and Langala are party symbols; respondent present with consent, no protest.
Allegation para 5(iii): Respondent published in 'The Kalinga' dated February 19, 1971 report of Marshaghai meeting containing appeal to religious symbols as in (i).

Allegation para 5(ii): At Marshaghai meeting February 15, 1971, respondent made false statements re personal character/conduct of Surendranath Dwivedi: Dwivedi not rendered account of Rs.1 lakh from Marwari Society Bombay and Rs.25,000 from Prime Minister during 1967 cyclone; statements false, respondent knew or did not believe true, calculated to prejudice Dwivedi's prospects.
Allegation para 5(iv): Report in 'The Kalinga' February 19, 1971 of Marshaghai meeting contained false statement re Dwivedi's character/conduct as in 5(ii), published by respondent or with consent.

Respondent denied all corrupt practice allegations in para 8 written statement; not editor of Feb 15/19 issues, no consent to publications; editorial/news not appeal to religious symbol but secular analogy; not present at Biju Patnaik speech; speech if made not with consent, not re election prospects.

Respondent denied making false statements at Marshaghai; if any reference to accounts, re public conduct not personal character; referred to public controversy re Dwivedi rendering accounts of relief funds from outside including Bihar Relief Committee.

Respondent produced letter Ext. L dated Jan 15, 1971 to Chairman Biju Patnaik: absent from HQ from Jan 19 till end of elections due to Lok Sabha campaign; J. Verma News Editor in charge of editing paper/news reports; endorsed by Chairman 'As PPD as proposed' Ext L/2, seen by J. Verma Ext L/3 same day.

Orissa High Court dismissed election petition on Jan 14, 1972; disbelieved petitioner's witnesses re meeting attendance/statements; believed respondent's witnesses/respondent re no such statements made, no concern with publications Ext.1/2 due to arrangements Exts L,L/2,L/3; statements if any re accounts re public not personal conduct.

Public controversy re Dwivedi rendering accounts: Prajatantra June 4, 1970 Ext A re mismanagement Utkal Relief Committee, Rs.24,960 advance to Dwivedi from Bihar Relief Rs.25,000; Dwivedi reply June 13 Ext 5; letters Sept 20/27 1970 Exts 3,4 demanding accounts of >1 lakh collected.
Dwivedi appeals: to Jayaprakash Narain Aug 15, 1969 Ext Z/5 for Bihar Relief donation; to Radhanath Rath Oct 16, 1969 Ext 9 for Rs.25,000 cheque.

legal_issues.text: Whether Ext.1 (editorial Feb 15), Ext.2 (news report Feb 19), and Biju Patnaik speech constitute corrupt practice under s.123(3) R.P. Act (appeal to religious symbols).
If so, whether published/made by respondent or with his consent.
Whether respondent's speech at Marshaghai Feb 15 re Dwivedi rendering accounts imputes against personal character/conduct (corrupt practice s.123(4)) or public conduct.
Whether Ext.2 report of respondent's speech published by/with consent of respondent.

petitioner_arguments.text: Ext.1 editorial, Ext.2 news reports, Biju Patnaik speech appeal to religious symbols Chakra/Langala as weapons of Jagannath/Balaram for respondent's prospects/prejudice others; respondent as editor published/with consent; speech at meeting in presence/with consent.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.123(3) Representation of the People Act, 1951

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondent's speech false statements re Dwivedi not accounting Rs.1 lakh Marwari Society Bombay, Rs.25,000 PM cyclone 1967; false, known false/not believed true, re personal character/conduct, prejudiced prospects; Ext.2 report thereof published/with consent.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.123(4) Representation of the People Act, 1951

petitioner_arguments.text: Presumption under s.7 Press Act as editor; not rebutted properly.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.7 Press and Registration of Books Act, 1867

respondent_arguments.text: No concern with Ext.1/2 publications; absent on leave per Ext.L from Jan19, J.Verma in charge; not authorized/consent; not appeal to religious symbols but secular analogy for development.
Not present at Biju Patnaik speech or did not consent/authorize; speech if made re strong govt, not election prospects, analogy not religious appeal.

No false statement re Dwivedi; referred to public controversy re duty to render public accounts of relief funds (Bihar Relief etc.), public not personal conduct; misreported; not calculated to prejudice parliamentary election (re assembly).

court_reasoning.text: To prove corrupt practice s.123(3): appeal to religious symbol for furtherance/prejudice; by candidate/agent/other with consent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Must prove publication/speech by/with consent of respondent.

court_reasoning.text: Respondent rebutted presumption s.7 Press Act via Ext.L etc.; Verma RW3 in charge; no evidence consent to Ext.1/2 or Biju speech; no agency/consent inferred from relations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court justified in accepting arrangements; no basis for consent inference.

court_reasoning.text: Petitioner's witnesses unreliable, tutored; no proof exact words/imputation of misappropriation (not pleaded); P.W.4 contradicts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Demand for public accounts re relief funds is public conduct, not personal character/conduct.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide if materials constitute corrupt practice absent consent proof; speech re public controversy, probable no reference to specific false sources.

holdings.text: No corrupt practice under s.123(3) proved: no consent to Ext.1/2 or Biju speech.
No corrupt practice under s.123(4): statement if made re public duty to account relief funds, not personal character; not proved false/imputed as pleaded.
Editor presumption rebutted by evidence of absence/arrangements.

precedents_cited.case_name: Samant N. Balakrishna etc. v. George Fernandez and Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Burden of proof for corrupt practices: by candidate/election agent avoids election without more; by other agent needs consent and material effect.

precedents_cited.case_name: D. P. Mishra v. Kamal Narain Sharma Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: No consent inferred from association alone for publication by editor; must prove authorization/responsibility.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Grounds to void election for corrupt practices; definition of appeal to religious symbols and false statements re personal character.

statutes_cited.name: Press and Registration of Books Act, 1867
statutes_cited.relevance: Presumption editor responsible for content rebuttable by evidence; declaration procedure.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed appeal with costs, upholding Orissa High Court dismissal of election petition; no corrupt practices proved against respondent as no consent to alleged publications/speeches, and statements re accounts not re personal character.

key_quotes.text: "Men in public life particularly those who collect monies for public or charitable purposes ought not to be sensitive when there is a demand to account for those amounts."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes public conduct demand for accounts from corrupt practice imputation against personal character.

key_quotes.text: "Consent or agency cannot be inferred from remote causes. Consent cannot be inferred from mere close friendship or other relationship or political affiliation."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects inference of consent from Biju Patnaik-respondent relations.

key_quotes.text: "The first class consists of corrupt practices committed by the candidate or his election agent or any other person with the consent of the candidate or his election agent. These, if established, avoid the election without any further condition being fulfilled."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes precedent on differing burdens for corrupt practices.
